table.name: acquisition
table.remarks: This represents the scanning of hybridized material. The output of this process is typically a digital image of an array.

table.name: acquisition_relationship
table.remarks: Multiple monochrome images may be merged to form a multi-color image. Red-green images of 2-channel hybridizations are an example of this.

table.name: acquisitionprop
table.remarks: Parameters associated with image acquisition.

table.name: arraydesign
table.remarks: General properties about an array. An array is a template used to generate physical slides, etc. It contains layout information, as well as global array properties, such as material (glass, nylon) and spot dimensions (in rows/columns).

table.name: arraydesignprop
table.remarks: Extra array design properties that are not accounted for in arraydesign.

table.name: assay
table.remarks: An assay consists of a physical instance of an array, combined with the conditions used to create the array (protocols, technician information). The assay can be thought of as a hybridization.

table.name: assay_biomaterial
table.remarks: A biomaterial can be hybridized many times (technical replicates), or combined with other biomaterials in a single hybridization (for two-channel arrays).

table.name: assay_project
table.remarks: Link assays to projects.

table.name: assayprop
table.remarks: Extra assay properties that are not accounted for in assay.

table.name: biomaterial
table.remarks: A biomaterial represents the MAGE concept of BioSource, BioSample, and LabeledExtract. It is essentially some biological material (tissue, cells, serum) that may have been processed. Processed biomaterials should be traceable back to raw biomaterials via the biomaterialrelationship table.

table.name: biomaterial_relationship
table.remarks: Relate biomaterials to one another. This is a way to track a series of treatments or material splits/merges, for instance.

table.name: biomaterial_treatment
table.remarks: Link biomaterials to treatments. Treatments have an order of operations (rank), and associated measurements (unittype_id, value).

table.name: biomaterialprop
table.remarks: Extra biomaterial properties that are not accounted for in biomaterial.

table.name: channel
table.remarks: Different array platforms can record signals from one or more channels (cDNA arrays typically use two CCD, but Affymetrix uses only one).

table.name: element
table.remarks: Represents a feature of the array. This is typically a region of the array coated or bound to DNA.

table.name: element_relationship
table.remarks: Sometimes we want to combine measurements from multiple elements to get a composite value. Affymetrix combines many probes to form a probeset measurement, for instance.

table.name: elementresult
table.remarks: An element on an array produces a measurement when hybridized to a biomaterial (traceable through quantification_id). This is the base data from which tables that actually contain data inherit.

table.name: elementresult_relationship
table.remarks: Sometimes we want to combine measurements from multiple elements to get a composite value. Affymetrix combines many probes to form a probeset measurement, for instance.

table.name: mageml
table.remarks: This table is for storing extra bits of MAGEml in a denormalized form. More normalization would require many more tables.

table.name: protocol
table.remarks: Procedural notes on how data was prepared and processed.

table.name: protocolparam
table.remarks: Parameters related to a protocol. For example, if the protocol is a soak, this might include attributes of bath temperature and duration.

table.name: quantification
table.remarks: Quantification is the transformation of an image acquisition to numeric data. This typically involves statistical procedures.

table.name: quantification_relationship
table.remarks: There may be multiple rounds of quantification, this allows us to keep an audit trail of what values went where.

table.name: quantificationprop
table.remarks: Extra quantification properties that are not accounted for in quantification.

table.name: treatment
table.remarks: A biomaterial may undergo multiple treatments. Examples of treatments: apoxia, fluorophore and biotin labeling.
